awd_titl_txt: Realistic modeling of star formation in cosmological simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most important goals of modern astrophysics is the detailed understanding of the formation and growth of galaxies. This project will add a refinement to models of the birth of star clusters in galaxies and their influence on the growth of the galaxy. They will include these models in simulations of the the growth of galaxies in the universe over the age of the universe. The results of these models will be used to compare with future observations from telescopes on the ground and in space.

This project will model the baryonic component of galaxies within LCDM cosmological simulations. The refinement to be made will treat stellar particles within the ART simulation as star clusters and add detailed properties of the evolution of the clusters and their influence on the local interstellar medium. With these refinements, zoom-in models of galaxies at redshifts of zero can have resolutions as small as 5 pc. From these simulations, they will produce simulated observational catalogs that can be compared with future observations from ALMA, JWST, and Gaia in order to constrain features of star formation and feedback within their models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project produced numerical simulations of the formation of Milky Way-sized galaxies with a realistic modeling of star formation. In this novel approach, each stellar particle represents a distinct bound star cluster, whose mass and formation timescale are limited by its own stellar feedback on the interstellar medium. We developed a technique for customizing initial conditions for galaxy formation simulations may be used by other research groups for consistent comparison of simulations using common well-tested initial conditions. This will enable more detailed code comparisons, as the confounding factor of groups using different initial conditions will be removed, and will allow the community to determine which aspects of galaxy formation are modeled most robustly.

The development of a new suite of galaxy formation simulations allows a deeper understanding of the interplay of multiple sources of stellar feedback on the self-regulation of star formation in high-redshift galaxies. We have determined that hypernova explosions have only a limited effect on galactic star formation history, while local efficiency of star formation has a strong effect on the mass function of young star clusters and thus can be constrained by observations. The stellar populations of MIlky Way-like galaxies at high redshift are dominated by massive star clusters, in sharp contrast to the local universe, but in agreement with the new JWST observations.

We have supplemented the simulations of high-redshift galaxies with a semi-analytical model that follows the dynamical disruption of these massive clusters until th epresent. Some of them evolve into globular clusters, whilke others disrupt fully into stellar streams. We created mock catalogs of model clusters and streams for three realizations of the galaxies most closely matching the Milky Way in its assembly history. These mock catalogs allow to test observational methods that attempt to reconstruct the merger history of the Milky Way using massive star clusters and stellar streams from disrupted clusters. We find that majority of the Galactic globular clusters formed in-situ, in the main progenitor of the Galaxy, while about 30% of the globular clusters formed ex-situ, in two most massive satellite galaxies that later merged with the Milky Way.
